1.words: All right. So we're going to go ahead and get started here. And if the other person joins us in another moment or so, I will just leave space for them to do the introduction and repeat myself a bit. But welcome everyone, I'm so glad to have you here. My name is Adrienne, and this is a conversation for the city of Cambridge. We're working with a partner called Cortico and their local voice network, to record these conversations. And the video of this conversation will be discarded, but the recording will become part of a public collection, the audio, a public collection for the local voice network platform, and shared with the city council and the mayor's office directly. The Cambridge City Council has launched a community engagement phase of the search for the new city manager. And that city manager will start in the summer of 2022. If you're wondering what the city manager does, they are responsible for providing leadership and making financial decisions for all city departments and services. And our city manager recommends policies and programs to the city council, and implements the city council legislation. The office connects directly with Cambridge residents, hosting neighborhood meetings and responding to inquiries and requests. Always working closely with city council to improve quality of life in our community. As Cambridge moves forward in this important process, we need a media input from the Cambridge ... The broader public. Because that's going to have an impact on the lives of people in our city. And we want to be really intentional and thorough to make sure that we're collecting feedback, and we're collecting it in many different ways including surveys, interviews, and focus groups. This conversation isn't any of that, it's not a survey, it's not an interview, it's not a focus group. It's an invitation, an open invitation for you to share your personal experience, and provide us with a perspective on how the city manager process could affect the lives of Cambridge residents. So we're asking for your honest input and perspective, we're thanking you for joining us. And before I begin like a flight attendant, I need you all to verbally consent to the fact that as a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to the city of Cambridge to use this recording in accordance with its mission. And you understand that the conversation will become part of the Local Voices Network collection, whose mission is to foster conversation and communities and in the media, to improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree with this, I would ask you verbally say, "I agree."

3.words: I heard one. I need six more.

8.words: Great. Okay. So we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to both share and learn from this conversation. So I have some ground rules and guidelines for the conversation. The first is to speak for yourself and ... Of your own experience. Allow others to speak for themselves, share time and allow others to finish speaking, taking turns. Stay curious and ask honest questions. Pause to take time for reflections. Listen generously, so assume good intentions, but recognize that your words have an impact. And when possible, try to close other unnecessary programs, applications, or notifications on your phone for the duration of this conversation. We have 90 minutes set aside. Is everyone on board with these guidelines, or is there anything that you'd like to add or change? All right. I'm going to take the silence as we're all on board with these guidelines. And to ease this conversation, we're going to use a modified circle process. Which means we're going to go in order to share for the first couple of questions. And I'm putting that order in the chat, and I will also say it out loud for anyone who is on the phone. Let me put that in the chat now, hopefully all can see that. So the order we're going to go in is, Sofia, Sarah with an H, Sarah, Halima, Anais and Grace. And I apologize if I've said anyone's name incorrectly, you'll have a chance to introduce yourself in a moment. I would like you to quickly go around say your first name, and then share a little bit about yourself, your background, like where you live or what your interest is, and why you are here today. So a value as it relates to why you are part of the conversation today. And just to ease everyone in doing that, I will start. Like I said, welcome everyone. My name is Adrienne. I am Mayor Siddiqui's constituent support manager. So I hear from constituents and residents in Cambridge all day long. I live in East Cambridge, and an important value for me that relates to this process is that ... And what I get to do in my job every day, is ensure that everyone's treated with dignity and respect by those in public power. So I get to do that by being the first stop for people who want to talk to the mayor, and by being involved in this process. And so I will pass the baton onto Sofia.

9.words: Hi, can you give me five please? I was having issues in the meeting a little while ago. I'm Sofia and I live in West Cambridge, and an important value to me I guess is, sharing your opinion which is why I'm in this meeting. Yeah.

10.words: Great. Thank you Sofia. Welcome. And Sarah with an H you're next.

11.words: Hi, I'm Sarah. I live in North Cambridge. The reason I'm here is because I think student voices are really important and listening to what they have to say.

12.words: Absolutely. That's part of the reason that we wanted to hold this forum, and I'll let you guys all know ... Or I should say, you women all know since we are ... I'm assuming based on names which I shouldn't do. But that the other two groups that I spoke to this morning highlighted that they wanted youth voices to be heard as part of this process. So I'm glad that you care about that, and know that others in the city that I'm speaking with also care about that. Sarah, without an H, would you go ahead please?

13.words: Yeah. Perfect. So my name is Sara. I live in Lower Cambridgeport for the rest of my life, even though I was born in Boston. And I feel like it is very important to this conversation definitely be able to get some thoughts. And would definitely help the city. So yeah.

14.words: Great. Thank you Sara. Halima would you introduce yourself please?

15.words: Hi, my name is Halima. I'm a junior at CRLS. I'm in this focus group, because I think it's important to also like Sarah said, to highlight student voices and to have student and be at the center of this. Yeah.

16.words: Wonderful and Anais. I'm sorry if I'm saying your name incorrectly.

17.words: No worries. Hi everyone, my name is Anise [Surname]. I'm a senior at CRLS, and I'm also one of the student members of the Cambridge School Committee. So I'm really interested in uplifting student voices, and hearing from my peers and providing that information to the committee. And I also live at 340 Harvard Street in Cambridge.

18.words: Great. Thank you Anise. And Grace?

19.words: Hi, my name is grace. I'm also a junior at CRLS, and I live in North Cambridge. I'm here today and like most of you said, to uplift student voices. And also not just the students that are here in this meeting today, but all the students around CRLS, even students that aren't involved in this work specifically. And making sure we get a diverse representation throughout the work that we're reporting back to city council. So yeah.

20.words: Great. Yeah. Thank you. So now we know who's here, we can get to the core of our conversation. As Cambridge begins to choose a new city manager, we want to make sure that this person knows about the issues that people in Cambridge are personally facing. So I would ask that you each think about a moment, because I'm going to ask you to share a story about a recent experience you've had in Cambridge that's made you think about or realize, a larger challenge that the city needs to tackle. We'll go around one at a time to share our stories. And please remember, since this is being recorded, not to use the names of other people when you tell your story. We'll go in the order that we did to introduce ourselves and that I put in the chat, and I'll guide us as well. I also want to just reiterate that you can opt out of sharing at anytime, and you can also ask for us to pass and come back to if you'd like us to do so. So I will give you just a moment to think about a story, and then when you're ready Sofia, please go ahead.

21.words: A big thing that I can think of is definitely public transportation. I don't know how much of it is just Cambridge or also both Cambridge and Boston and just like the greater boss area in general. But I definitely think there's a lot of room for improvement in terms of our public transportation. Yeah.

22.words: Great. Thank you. And Sarah with an H, if you are ready go ahead.

23.words: I'm going to just take a few more minutes to think.

24.words: Absolutely. And the question which I'll put in the chat just to repeat it is, we are asking you to share a story or a recent experience that you've had in Cambridge, that's made you think about or realize a larger challenge the city needs to tackle. Let me just type that up in a chat here.

25.words: I can actually go now, I think I thought of something. Mine has to do more at CRLS and AP classes, and just noticing how we always make an effort to just incorporate as many students as possible, but it's still not happening. And it's not reaching all students at CRLS in terms of diversity. So that's a challenge that I think Cambridge still needs to tackle. Giving resources and telling other students about these classes they can be taking.

26.words: Great. Thank you Sarah for sharing that. And that actually did come up on a different call that I had today. It's good to have overlap in the issues that are being raised. And so thank you for raising that. The other Sara if you're ready.

27.words: I am fully ready, yeah. So I would say, Affordable housing. Definitely, there's not so much affordable housing I see, although I know some places that do have it. But affordable housing is such a big characteristic. I would say let's talk with the council and the governor about that. But yeah, it's really such a big issue.

28.words: Yeah. Housing is definitely up there on the list of things that other people have raised, so thank you for raising that as well. Halima?

30.words: Sure, absolutely. Anise, are you ready?

31.words: Yes. So a story that I have and an experience that I think Cambridge can more effectively challenge is, the issue of unhoused people in Cambridge and providing resources. Specifically every week, I volunteer at the Harvard Square Homeless Shelter and often at the First Church Shelter. Where I notice that a lot of the guests really do have goals on becoming a part of independent housing, and being able to use their experiences to really further develop what they want to do with life. And I think Cambridge really can take a greater stand on providing opportunities for unhoused people. And where it be housing, food, shelter, or even just having different kinds of options or services that can better aid with really truly deciding and knowing what to do going forward.

32.words: Great. Yeah. Thank you Anise. There's been a working group for the homeless population that I've been able to be a part of as the mayor's representative. So I think absolutely that you're right, and that's an important issue for the next city manager. We'll go to Grace before we go back to Halima. Grace, are you ready?

33.words: Yeah. I have two that aren't fully thought out yet, but there's just two ideas that have come up recently in school for me. One was, health, sex education in school. I was reflecting back on my experiences, and what I've received in middle school and how it was very little. And I've had to learn that outside of school, and not all ... Not every child has that resources to have parents that can have a conversation of feminine hygiene or conversations like that that aren't necessarily you can feel comfortable having them with everyone. So maybe implementing those classes in middle school. I know I had a couple but they weren't in depth, and they really weren't considered a really safe space to get your questions answered. Also kids don't feel like they have to go out of their way to ask what could be an embarrassing question. And then two, I did a lot of equity work recently in the beginning of the year, I ran the equity summit with a couple other of my friends. And a lot of things that came up was, changing curriculums into a more diverse perspective rather than a more white perspective, especially with history. And then also incorporating more books with students that ... Or represent ... Books that have more representation again for all students, mainly in middle and elementary school. I guess it engages students more seeing representation of someone they see in their literature. So I just think those two. Those two have come up recently and I think they're both pretty important.

34.words: Great. Thank you Grace. And Halima, are you ready?

35.words: Yes, I am. Just like Grace I have two. One of ours overlaps in terms of education. I think educating students on ... Sorry, their rights more specifically under title nine, or how to report issues in their building and things like that. Because that's been a huge issue among students of not knowing who to go to when something is happening, and how to ... What the process is and things like that. And then I think the second one would be the school to prison pipeline that we have, and the whole extension school. Just because there has been an issue of extra security in the hallways, and that whole thing of anti-bias training and ... As not going off of your implicit bias and rather thinking through the situation. Because it can be harmful to students to have security consistently stop you in the hallways, or for people not to look out for you. So yeah.

36.words: Great. Thank you Halima for raising that. These are all really important issues, so thank you all. The next section is going to be a little bit less coordinated in that, we want to move to a conversation about your hopes and concerns for the next city manager in our community. So I have a few questions that we can start with, but I want this to be a time that you guys can reflect and build, have some back and forth between yourselves to share stories. And if there's a point that resonate for you, feel free to chime in. We do want to be mindful that everyone who wants to participate has a chance to do so. So I'll start with the first question, and then I have two more. And so the first question is, from your experience, what do you see as the positive role or roles that the city Cambridge government, or the city manager more specifically, plays in our community today? Please share a story from your experience that will help give us a picture about what you like and why. So this is a positive role, the Cambridge city government plays. And if you can be specific to the Cambridge city manager even better, but if you can't that's okay. We're going to start with that positive role, and know that the second question is negative role, or the concern you have. So there will be space for both. And I'm opening the floor to whoever feels motivated to answer.

37.words: An experience I've had with the city manager and the city council was, a few years ago I was working with the women's historical society and we're trying to put up a statue commemorating the hundredth anniversary of women getting the right to vote, which was now two years ago in 2020. And the city manager and the city council allowed us ... Gave us a lot of money to work with, space to work with, and just the general construction rights and all that complicated government stuff in terms of getting up this statue. Unfortunately since then COVID has complicated a lot of things about that in general. But it was I think a really good experience, and it was awesome to see that stuff can get done or at least people can try to make change in the ... Yeah, for the community and stuff like that. That's my experience.

39.words: I can go. So I can't think of a negative one but a positive one that I have. I can't think of an event, but usually being in the community that's what I like to see. One of the city come council members and the city manager being the community, that's what I see that's a positive role. Because that person actually cares, that person actually know [inaudible] with the people. So they know the actual problems and solutions. Actually, I do apologize if there's noise, I'm just in my actual dining room. So, yeah.

40.words: No problem. And I'm typing the prompt into the chat, so I'm just going to mute myself so you don't all hear my typing. But anyone else who wants to jump in?

41.words: I can go. I think a positive thing that is just having a lot of resources or community centers that people can go to. Well, I think there is improvement in that area. I just think there's a ... They do a really good job at having extracurriculars for students, and places for parents to go, and places for people to get help and any resources that they need, and generally available to people. So I think we do a really good job at that.

42.words: I also think for example, right now they do a really good job of assuring that students get a voice in these conversations. Reaching out to students, going to high school, having one on one conversations. Introducing themselves and just giving an opportunity that we wouldn't necessarily have initially, to be able to put in our two cents of what we want our school to look like, because ultimately it is our education. So I think it's really important when instead of speaking for students, they have students speak for themselves. So I think that's been really something that Cambridge has done really well on.

43.words: Something similar to what grace said, I think Cambridge does a really good job of providing spaces for people to share their opinions, students and parents and even teachers. So that's always been really helpful, because you know that they're making an attempt to listen.

44.words: Just to echo what Halima and Sarah said, I also think that Cambridge is very good at creating spaces for people to come and share their opinions. And then also they're often good at hearing these thoughts of the community, and trying to integrate those opinions and ideas into their work and policy motions. And so that can be really beneficial to not only hear from the community, but then to incorporate what the community said into their work.

45.words: Great. Thank you all. If anyone wants to jump in, please do so. Otherwise, if you want to share the exact same prompt except a concern about the role of the Cambridge government or the city manager that you have and are comfortable sharing that with us, we can go to that next. I know one of you said you didn't have any negative or concerns, but if any of you have a concern about the role of the city manager or Cambridge government that you want to air it now, please go ahead.

46.words: I can go. While I do think Cambridge does make the effort to talk to several families and students and teachers, I don't always think it reaches as many groups as it needs to that represents Cambridge. I definitely think there's an effort, but it's just not always successful. And I know it can be really hard to reach every single group. But I think that more voices can be heard when having conversations.

47.words: Thank you Sarah. Yeah, we're hosting 18 of these conversations as well as the focus groups and interviews. So we're really trying to get as broad a perspective and input as we can. But I think you're exactly right that there might be an effort, but that doesn't necessarily mean that it's successful. So thank you for raising that. I'm comfortable with silence so ... Go ahead.

48.words: So I personally I'm not completely aware with all the roles and responsibilities of the city manager. But I do think that of the roles that I know of the city manager is often able to just decide a lot of aspects of Cambridge for themselves without seeking the input of individuals, or even from the council, or without a vote. Or even sometimes the council wants to do something and the city manager all by themselves just are able to say no. So I know this isn't necessarily the aspect of the person, because it's more of the integrated role itself. But I do think it would be a lot more beneficial if some of this power was given to the city council or school committee, especially when a lot of the motions are related to school specific aspects. I think that could be really helpful to go to the school committee instead of just this one person deciding for themselves.

49.words: Yeah. Thank you Anise. I think that's something that's been reflected in a lot of the conversations that I've had so far. The city council hires the city manager to be the lead administrator for the city and in charge of all the city agencies. And so while the city manager is tasked with executing the city council legislation, there are ... They have the final say in a lot of matters, budgetary specifically among other things. Part of the reason that that was put into place was to avoid politics, essentially interfering in corruption. So this person isn't elected, which means that ideally they wouldn't be responding to corporate money in the same way that a politician could be. However, then you face the less democratic person that wasn't elected making the decisions in the city. And so there's a balancing act there. And Cambridge is unique in the way that this is executed, like a hired CEO that responds to the board. So that's I think really helpful to hear your perspective on that. All right. Well, if somebody wants to come back to this at a later point, we are welcome to do so. I will pose some other questions for you. One is, I would like us to imagine our ideal city manager together, and collectively share some of the key traits and skills that that person would have. The job description is written and that's determined by the charter that can't be changed. But are there specific skills and traits that you want the next city manager to have? Is one question. And the other question ... And I'll put these in the chat as soon as I say them is, what do you hope is different in our Cambridge community five years from now, once the city manager has had time in their position? So I'm going to just mute myself to type these into the chat, and feel free to chime in as you're ready. And apologies for any typos or capitalization issues as I type as quickly as possible on the chat there.

50.words: Can they just be one word traits?

52.words: Okay. I would say outgoing and understanding, especially if you either haven't grown up in Cambridge or lived in Cambridge, understand that there's different parts of the community and different struggles in each part of the community. And also that it's important to make connections in all of those communities rather than just one that you connect with the most. And then also five years from now, I'm not exactly sure. I'll think and then...

58.words: All right. So definitely I would say enthusiastic, hardworking and a positive attitude. I would love a person who have a positive attitude. But not only that, cooperative got to be cooperative with other people. And that's all I have.

59.words: Thanks Sara. It sounds like you're enthusiastic and positive, so I'm glad you set those traits.

61.words: I can go. I would say, I think unity and just more of a community, because lately I've just been seeing splits students and administration, or just I don't know, just the community in itself. So just seeing more unity in the next five years.

62.words: Great. Thanks Halima. And the other Sarah with an H, did you want to go?

63.words: Yeah. I was also going to say enthusiastic, because someone who's enthusiastic about the city will make other people enthusiastic. But also someone who can handle criticism, because that's the only way they can improve.

64.words: I think open-mindedness is really important in a position with so much power. Just being able to hear a bunch of different perspectives.

65.words: For me, definitely what's most important is since it's a hired position as opposed to an elected position, but it still holds so much power. Just someone who represents the community and is willing go out and figure out what people actually would benefit from, and what needs to change about the community.

66.words: Great, yeah. Representative of the community, that's one that I've heard a lot today. So, great. Thank you. So now we would invite you to think about this conversation as a way to raise your voice beyond this group. What's one thing you'd want your future Cambridge city manager to hear from this conversation? And if there's anything that you've heard today that you'll be taking away from the conversation or would want other people to hear. So something you want the city manager to hear, and something that you might take away or share with others from this conversation today.

67.words: Could you put the question in the chat?

68.words: Yes. I'll type it in there.

69.words: Something I would want my future Cambridge city manager to hear, is to really try to work with schools and the school committee when thinking about students. Especially this past year with COVID, I think a lot of the decisions were made based on the general Cambridge public. But I don't think students are always thought about in a sense. I mean, I'm really grateful for all the work that was done to center students, and really make sure that they were getting the best education that they could in such a difficult time. But I think it would've just been even better if the city manager could have worked with the schools and the school committee more.

70.words: Agreed. I think building a relationship with the schools and the students would be really beneficial. Just to either explain what their role is and how we can part participate, or just get more students and families involved in what's going on for families who aren't ... Some families who aren't as aware. Yeah, I think being an active member in the community as if you were a parent I guess or a student, keeping up with what's going on, showing up to student events I think would be really beneficial. Because then also students and families would feel comfortable making a relationship with the city manager, which is also you can get more information to work with city council. So I think that is also really important.

71.words: I completely agree with Anise and Grace. I think that just interacting more with the students, and listening to students and staff is really important. Even visiting clubs could be really great. It doesn't have to be a continuous thing, but just stopping by and just talking to students and hearing what they have to say would be really great.

72.words: Yeah. I'd just like to echo that I agree with the both of them. I just think I didn't know who the first city manager was, and that says a lot. So just having that unity or just knowing that that person even exists and you can't talk to them.

73.words: Absolutely. For anyone who doesn't know the current city manager is Louis [Surname]. And that's a really important point, if you don't know who he is or what his role is, power that he has had in the city. And at least one thing from this process that we can share out is that, and I don't want to say he for the next city manager, because I want to hold onto my dream that it might be female.

74.words: I actually want to say something. So I feel like a city manager should have again, positive mindset, but have a vision for the city. There's a lot of youth around here, and especially a lot of community centers. Do something fun for the youth, make something happen for the youth. That's the thing. The young generation is about to grow, and then help be in this other generation I would say. We are witnessing that, and it's crazy because young people can now make a change of something using a free speech voice. We want to make sure that the city manager listens to the youth, beats with the youth. And just make sure that the youth never gets let out. Which means, we should always make sure that the youth are also part of this agenda too. And I would say for other people to see this or hear that ... Always think about the things that would make sure that the other generation will be able to see. And I see big potential for the new city manager, and so I am ready to see that. And that's clearly just a sentence or a speech I just said, but I say, "I'm fine with that." And I'm hoping that the current city manager ... I'm hoping he's doing well and ... Because there is a new city manager coming in, I'm hoping that he gets thanks for what he does. Because I did see some good positive things happening as city. So, yeah.

75.words: Thank you Sara. And this conversation will be transcribed. It's being recorded, so the information will go ... The recording will go to the city council and to the mayor's office, and you all will get a copy of it as well. So you can listen back or reflect on what others had said. And the other conversations that we're hosting, the other 18 conversations will also be publicly accessible to you all written and recording. So I just want to note that since some of you are raising the issue of transparency and ongoing impact of student voices.

76.words: Wait a second, I think I have a good idea. I mean, I don't know if I can share some ideas of how we're going to do this, but maybe we can have some type of event. Not a big event but ... So, Cambridge residents have them all pack into a nice auditory maybe at CRLs or King Open or CSUS, have them there. Maybe we can actually also do this towards ... We can do a ton of other events also, just do it by borough to borough. Have them be the speakers, and have the counselors and a city manager who is current. Listen, I see that as a potential, and if I can be involved with that, that would be great.

77.words: Yeah. So Sara, this will go directly to the vice mayor who's running the search process. So certainly the ideal will get passed on. There was a meeting this Sunday passed with about 90 people, and the vice mayor and the search company that's been hired for this process. So there were about 90 people that gave input. But someone I spoke with earlier today highlighted that there weren't any youth representatives there, so this is an idea that will go back to the council and the next city manager will also hear. So thank you for raising that. And I think it's an important point.

79.words: So those are the questions we have for you. We still have plenty of time. I want to remind you what's going to happen with the thoughts that you just shared, are, recordings will be transcribed and up loaded to lvn.org. It's a web-based tool to listen and explore the conversations. On lvn.org you can search the conversation, listen to audio snippets and discover patterns. You'll receive an invitation to join that platform, to listen to your own conversation and other after the conversation is uploaded and transcribed. I'm going to stay on the call, but if any of you need to go or we can go back to any of the other questions. I want to leave the floor open to you. As I said, I'm comfortable with silence or if you need to take the time to reflect longer, I'm going to stay here. But wanted to just give the wrap up information for anyone who needs to hop off.

80.words: Well, thank you so much Adrienne. I do have to go, but it was awesome to be a part of this meeting, and it was nice to meet everyone as well. Bye.

86.words: I have tutoring so I do have to run. But thank you for this opportunity again.

90.words: Well, I also have to leave too, unfortunately. I'm sorry that I have to leave you out. But I thank you for everything and thank you for making the CRLS conversation. That was actually fun.

91.words: Absolutely Sara, thanks for your contribution and have a great rest of your day.
